answer.content:
Sharding is partitioning a large database across multiple servers (nodes).

Instead of one server holding 1TB of data, you have 10 servers holding 100GB each. A **Shard Key** determines which server a piece of data lives on.

title: Replication Factor
ques: In a distributed DB, what does a **Replication Factor (RF)** of 3 mean?

answer.content:
It means every piece of data is stored on **3 different servers**.

**Benefit:** If one server dies, you have 2 other copies. If two servers die, you still have 1 copy. This guarantees high availability and durability.

title: Consistent Hashing
ques: What algorithm allows adding/removing servers in a cluster with minimal data movement?

answer.content:
**Consistent Hashing.**

When a new node joins the cluster, only keys that map to its position on the 'ring' need to be moved to it. Without this, resizing a cluster would require reshuffling nearly all data.

When you read data, the coordinator node checks all replicas.

If one replica has outdated data (due to a missed write), the coordinator sends the correct data to it in the background to bring it back in sync ('repairing' it).
